document.title: National Standards for Personal Financial Education

jurisdiction.title: Jump$tart Coalition for Personal Financial Literacy

4433020716DD454B8F6F632E47AC2053.description:
Describe steps people can take to safely manage their
finances using mobile technology

AAF4423384504E23B0B8C78203AE8419.description:
List actions that an individual can take to protect personal
identification information.

2ECA0C33138B499196C83C8A3E970261.description:
Explain methods used by identity thieves to obtain
personal information to commit a crime.

8EBC6A9A7616450FB92E7B566B6951A2.description:
Identity theft is the use of
someone else’s personal
identification information to
commit a crime.

96AD2AD91D024B259EB5C8878794ED2F.description:
Analyze the costs and benefits of purchasing an extended
warranty on a specific item (e.g. cellphone, laptop, or
vehicle).

1E2832F8458F49909DCBA9067ED25149.description:
Describe types of purchases where extended warranties
are typically offered as an add-on purchase.

24BED2B193504364BF715FFC5824C9D1.description:
Extended warranties and
service contracts provide
protection against certain
product mechanical failures
during the contract period.

FB230361B27445B591204FA94A180F24.description:
Weigh the costs and benefits of buying cell phone
insurance versus accepting the risk.

B0ADB4C9782B4836AE4C7193A51B5789.description:
Identify ways in which an automobile driver can avoid,
reduce, or transfer the risk of being in a crash.

0E43E9BF7C1744A7B9A5E5DB2F763924.description:
Give examples of how people manage the risk of financial
loss through risk avoidance, reduction, retention, and
transfer.

2C05CF5D9DAC4DADA8997B6FBADEB36B.description:
People can choose to avoid,
reduce, retain, or transfer
risk through the purchase of
insurance. Each option has
different costs and benefits.

6DE6E8D513094D6D9F6380362FAFCE82.description:
Given information about premiums, deductibles,
copayments, and coinsurance, calculate out-of-pocket
costs for a hypothetical insured loss.

2FFAEF3ED1684A1EB5C8C17422830FD7.description:
Describe how each of the following out-of-pocket
insurance costs affects policyholders: premium,
deductible, copayment, and coinsurance.

D5A60364957E4F2A8C1AA78BF47B5EB1.description:
Four key insurance terms that
contribute to out-of-pocket
costs with an insurance
policy are: premium,
deductible, copayments, and
co-insurance.

05D11EEFD0E2452D8D3AEEA4BDA1D187.description:
Explain why insurers commonly charge higher premiums
to people who are higher risk (e.g. auto insurance for
drivers with a bad accident record, flood insurance for
houses on the coastline).

B406740FBDCF4DA5849C536A3EA9A01F.description:
Discuss how people use insurance to share the risk of
financial loss.

080F4505238F415B85262611A2516BD0.description:
An insurance company
creates a pool of funds from
many policyholders’ premium
payments and then uses
these funds to compensate
customers who experience a
loss. People at higher risk for
making a claim usually have
to pay a higher premium.

BA1E039DEFC245B390C06BDE97B8E64D.description:
Explain what might happen to people who cannot afford
to buy insurance for a particular risk or who choose not to
buy it.

DB8874D200F642B0AF8FC0F0FC1E72C2.description:
Describe ways in which having insurance can protect a
person from financial loss.

7AA8AED802BB4F30A4E056224F82F655.description:
Insurance is a financial
product that allows people
to pay a fee (premium)
to transfer the cost of a
potential financial loss to an
insurance company.

3292B3B70CFD4464B432D36C248DF20D.description:
Explain how advance planning can reduce the financial
impact of an event that causes damage to personal
property

B140D6663F6D49FD865690EACCD30A67.description:
Describe how an unexpected event that damages health
or property can impact a family’s financial situation.

410FFF8DDBAE4B32A160064A6AF15E0F.description:
Financial loss can occur
from unexpected events
that damage health, wealth,
income, property, and/or
future opportunities.

A21DDB9B751940ABBC88B70A53028E19.description:
Predict the possible consequences of having a lot of debt
payments relative to income.

555B96D26C704779B43624AB8684FB8E.description:
Identify indicators that a person has accumulated too
much debt.

F3F0ADD9AFF44E0692C18D76F5DD4611.description:
Borrowing increases debt
and can negatively affect a
person’s finances.

0A4400E8B27E4DF896361AA5E5728E03.description: Justify the use of credit for a specific purchase.

63854ED855B847CB919FE965BCA7D822.description:
Assess the benefits and costs of using credit to finance
education and housing versus using credit to purchase
food and clothing.

04B4219E6FAD4494AC8A1FF2DC9D5CB4.description:
Explain why using credit to finance education and
housing could be beneficial.

B17A0B195ABA41948BC379664F2DF978.description:
When people borrow money
to invest in higher education
or housing, the risks and
costs may be outweighed by
the future benefits.

FA9B71F7200C4F06BB4239882A345CD1.description:
Discuss how a borrower’s credit history can impact their
borrowing costs.

962EE2A57BFA486FB09BFADCB99B814C.description:
Identify the types of information contained in a credit
report.

43D7C4C75F9049DD9DE0ABF854C961A7.description:
Lenders charge different
interest rates based on
borrower risk of nonpayment,
which is commonly evaluated
using information in the
borrower’s credit report.

0889C676FBEA4931BB0F78160774C1A5.description:
Describe how a credit card user can minimize interest
charges on their credit card purchases.

ACD34594F7A043B58F9338B1362D7FF8.description:
Explain why credit card interest rates tend to be higher
than rates for secured loans, such as automobile loans.

2C8D6CB07F5247739DBC6E409D90DBF8.description:
Credit cards typically charge
higher interest rates on
balances due compared with
rates on other types of loans.

267837505EDB43E8B45AC617C84347D4.description:
For a given monthly payment, loan amount, and loan
repayment period, calculate the total amount of interest
paid by the borrower.

395DB94E7B3D47D0913642BE0E8D5774.description:
Describe the effect of higher interest rates and longer
loan terms on the total cost of a loan.

1E3EF68426434C869CEE9E9DC6EB4A8D.description:
The longer a loan repayment
period and the higher the
interest rate, the larger the
total amount of interest paid
by a borrower.

BD22FF9D830C448CA8568A7C69897F07.description:
Investigate what happens to a low introductory interest
rate when the borrower misses a payment or makes a late
payment.

C2E3E3E2691A423DBCE40A38F1E9E0FB.description: Calculate APR, given annual interest and loan amount.

4EA2CB7A26B04678B3E7136A71FDEEAB.description:
Describe how lenders advertise loan costs to potential
borrowers.

914E5E6496364455A734DDDCD55FE547.description:
Financial institutions
advertise loan costs to
potential borrowers using
the Annual Percentage
Rate (APR), expressed as
an annual percentage of
the loan principal. Low
introductory rates offered
to attract customers may
increase later.

6E9E1C64135B4E5BAE60389467F76B06.description: Explain how market conditions impact interest rates.

AE9C17259A134265ADC3094434F4C778.description:
Compare lenders based on type of credit offered, interest
rates, and fees.

F0AED80D85214D60A9EAB0C159D4E1E6.description:
Identify financial institutions and businesses that offer
consumer credit.

862D3F736ED84A40A921579BDFFB8840.description:
Interest rates and fees vary
by type of lender, type of
credit, and market conditions.

315274F151D34C48885E14905AB21CDE.description:
Demonstrate the difference in wealth accumulation for a
person who begins to invest regularly at age 30 versus
someone who starts at age 40.

E2EA68E0144F415A91ECCC3B0BB2D844.description:
Estimate the future value of a regular series of equal
annual investments for a specified period of time and rate
of return.

7976FF70CCC74A7D9A8A201AEB73373D.description:
Estimate the future value of a lump sum invested today for
a specified period of time and rate of return.

15A3B361345148BAB27A514697763C90.description:
The benefits of compounding
for building wealth are
greatest for people who
invest regularly over longer
periods of time.

654B4E2CE23449D9A6162E1C012C0AC3.description:
Identify investments that would be most appropriate for
people who are uncomfortable with taking financial risk.

389C5728186F44F7A9021BCEFBE713DB.description:
Compare rates of return on different types of investments
and order them by risk.

678084B6A5634A93A4C1B422BAEB0028.description:
Different types of
investments expose investors
to different degrees of risk.

2AA1DE624F2349B985F30B002E21C6CA.description:
Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of investing in
a diversified stock or bond mutual fund versus individual
stocks and bonds.

BFCE457D44BC42D4BD8786D1539A17CE.description:
Explain the concept of investment diversification both
within and among different asset classes.

88978756E8364EBB8DDCE1FDFFF72592.description:
Instead of buying individual
stocks and bonds, investors
can buy shares of pooled
investments such as mutual
funds and exchange-traded
funds (ETFs).

4C3F6F43EC0F4A2DB14905D1FFAE5053.description:
Explain the potential risks and rewards of investing in
corporate stock.

878B4DE02A184806B2804A9F524E5B96.description:
Select a stock and find the dividends it paid last year and
how much the price of the stock has changed over the
year.

AECC45204CB3409EA8D6CFC43665396D.description:
Investors who buy corporate
stock become part-owners
of a business, benefit from
potential increases in the
value of their shares, and may
receive dividend income.

BC7566945902450F92DF468340A27F87.description:
Calculate the amount of annual interest income an
investor would receive from a corporate bond offering at a
given coupon interest rate.

4E238775245A4A36AB15B4329BE1527A.description:
Investors who buy corporate
or government bonds are
lending money to the issuer
in exchange for regular
interest payments.

CB1C4AD9900342D3B8C15EE564F128D3.description:
Discuss how some financial assets can be harder to sell
quickly (e.g. stocks traded on an exchange versus real
estate).

0BC7F5AEBCDA4C66BEC046A883743317.description:
Demonstrate how to find the current prices of stocks,
bonds, and mutual funds.

BC4BD1C3A1FE48348022DD999B423A15.description: Define common types of financial assets.

4E9499E3517C4E88BA6A14F5E1C87A89.description:
Common types of financial
assets include certificates of
deposit (CDs), stocks, bonds,
mutual funds, and real estate.

3A4A483DC16E474AA971BE2797CC2C2E.description:
Explain why some people might prefer to buy investments
that grow in value over time instead of investments that
pay regular income.

4C3B63873BCD4B5B81A2C128A9D7F47D.description:
List the potential benefits of investing money in a financial
asset.

82FA67232AAA45F0BDA0D6B36A19FEFC.description:
Investors in financial assets
expect an increase in value
over time (capital gain) and/
or receipt of regular income,
such as interest or dividends.

8F08C3BAAE04483AB70CCE6473156227.description:
Identify types of accounts that do not offer deposit
insurance.

1A48E35DD49140CCB26DE027CA224367.description:
Compare Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC)
and National Credit Union Administration (NCUA)
insurance coverage limits for checking and savings
accounts offered at financial institutions.

C607664A57AC494A9E53A32F4DA92283.description: Explain the importance of federal deposit insurance.

8A655447843F4B749FA891E978156400.description:
Checking and saving deposit
accounts in many financial
institutions are insured up to
certain limits by the federal
government.

C405B93DE68445878A22B3913024F441.description:
Demonstrate how annual interest earned increases over
time when both the original principal and earned interest
are left in a savings account.

2607A44AEF954FEC90DE80FC24B10672.description:
Explain the benefit of compound interest as compared
with simple interest.

3ED03B0115C3431699A6D302FA94169C.description:
Compound interest is
interest on both the original
principal and previously
earned interest, as compared
to simple interest which is
only interest on the original
principal.

EC72513ADCFD4A9087C56CF7A221F589.description:
Use the Rule of 72 to approximate how many years it will
take for savings to double in value at different rates of
interest.

E9CCAD8D8F724A0BAF01500E9BEB343B.description:
Demonstrate how earning a higher interest rate on money
in a savings account will help a person to reach their
savings goal sooner.

1D02C276F70A46F28C3CFED7A40E17BD.description:
Interest earned on savings is
the interest rate multiplied by
the balance in the account,
which includes the original
amount saved (principal) and
previously earned interest.

FE1F6E21D1AF4EF4AD5DD5B7825AF793.description:
Explain how financial institutions get the money to pay
interest to their customers who deposit money in savings
accounts.

EFEF2DB50683412886E221ACCF834DD4.description:
Compare the interest rate paid by a financial institution
on savings accounts to the interest charged by the same
institution on loans.

C42463BD7CC243119CCACFACD2D5101A.description:
Compare and contrast different types of financial
institutions and their products and services.

E8FB54813BE945EA9022D6FEF5113CF0.description:
Financial institutions pay
interest to depositors and
loan out the money to
borrowers who pay interest
on their loans.

9F3C790A31284E01BF48FF1E7E0894A9.description: Discuss how savings decisions can affect financial wellbeing.

72E33BF74FF44DCC9401507B8D74E241.description:
Identify life situations that can make it difficult for a
person to save or to stick to a savings plan.

848809B6D86949F1A948D6520C129B0E.description:
Explain how a person’s personality type might affect their
willingness to save or to stick to a savings plan.

2403131743F14F9B95027787934E1120.description:
Compare personal attitudes toward saving to those of a
friend or relative.

5F8B1386A62C40BF9F8BC60AC9E480C6.description:
Savings decisions depend
on individual preferences
and circumstances, and can
impact personal satisfaction
and financial well-being.

E0C91A4BE6D34562A953C3AB16A43AFF.description:
Create a savings plan that will allow someone to make a
large purchase in one year, 5 years, and 10 years.

FA9FC8C344D14AF1BC00D8D67986A091.description:
Identify the most common reasons that people save
money for the future.

C3936776224745D89BF3D7AACA7DDE97.description:
People save money for many
different purposes, including
large purchases such as cars
and homes, education costs,
retirement, and emergencies.

B2C0B572A5964869A2E07D18FD104F8E.description:
Choose and justify a preferred payment method for
purchases of at least three different types of goods and
services.

8A7F49D869BF40A3B05E1E20B247363D.description:
Summarize the advantages, disadvantages, risks, and
protections of various payment methods.

7AE25BE3B5AA4D5BB9A9AFCBF667B5BA.description:
Explain how various payment methods are used to
purchase goods and services.

D58D52EB95CA45D3A0A58E5C5A403F28.description:
Explain the difference between a debit card and a credit
card.

5AD30D5B105743BAA3585E87897F117E.description:
Consumers weigh the costs
and benefits of different
payment methods to
determine the best option
for purchasing goods and
services.

6B1D94B876DA4C0BA8DB06480DD8DA72.description:
Identify sources of product information that are less
useful for buying decisions due to incentive conflicts of
the information provider.

3D172B256AE54E1ABEFFCEB19A7A37B4.description:
Assess strengths and weaknesses of various online and
printed sources of product information.

79329750E76F421AA0BDFC62CE77D46A.description:
Evaluate information about goods and services based on
reliability and accuracy of the source.

9A8EE47A8374426E9C57561B1D491D1C.description:
When evaluating information
about goods and services, a
consumer can better assess
the quality and usefulness
of the information by
understanding the incentives
of the information provider.

B81E4306F87843A7AD0F4A0166BBD890.description:
Discuss ways to verify a claim expressed in advertising
for an age-appropriate product.

F9B5890023A5443DA7C3A64B8720B14F.description:
Identify misleading or deceptive information about
consumer goods or services found in online and print
sources.

1AC8DB0D012C458EB85996B9C79A8166.description:
Explain the types of information most helpful in making a
purchase decision.

C074E7081179437C8A61C5F057903081.description:
Select an item and gather information from the
manufacturer’s website, retail websites, and consumer
review websites.

7093EA8A03A241A9AEA3499C9A97CA9B.description:
Making an informed purchase
decision requires a consumer
to critically evaluate price,
product claims, and quality
information from a variety of
sources.

8489B66F9F7F41A6AE7F3D6629B3CEB7.description:
Discuss the budgeting challenges faced by people living
on minimum wage.

13AC4B4079A8402DA11FCD1FFDE827D0.description:
Explain why people with identical incomes make different
choices for spending, saving, and managing money.

78BC491238B744C68AF4D1D596C9A8A4.description:
Create a budget that includes expenses and savings out
of a given amount of income.

7DC9B76A623B48899AE3ADBDE8310209.description: Identify personal goals for spending and saving.

C965EDD0EB46454E9728970B1F2C1930.description:
Creating a budget can help
people make informed
choices about spending,
saving, and managing money
in order to achieve financial
goals.

C68898C8BDB643DDADD3DA451604940A.description: Research common reasons for new business failures.

9A74D35520F844D7BC7ECC159F76A82A.description:
Discuss why starting a new business could be riskier
than other career choices.

11F81845086D4952AEE36102E32B3DEA.description:
Investigate the motivating factors to being self-employed
or working as an independent contractor in the “gig”
economy.

82E520FDC72F43ABBA7119995A06A13B.description:
Entrepreneurs gain
satisfaction from working
for themselves and expect
to earn profits that will
compensate for the risks
associated with new
business ventures.

0A7B192419BF48C58A40564DAE915D0A.description:
Give several examples of personal circumstances that
qualify for government income support or assistance.

F774096B2C104DA383775C6508519EBA.description:
Explain the financial situation addressed by Medicaid and
SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program).

525183BD3F4E414D934D0BD8230398DC.description:
The government provides
income support and
assistance for people who
qualify based on low income
or other criteria.

6B5AD885C6DB4479B6F8548A37EDD59E.description:
Research the consequences of failing to pay income
taxes.

885CE5857783445DADC16B5F4B87B41D.description: Describe how taxes are paid on tip income.

854D5A44F371421DA991EE7C19C6B105.description:
Illustrate the relationship between income level and
income tax paid.

55A94DD0BC7B4448BAEBB250474CBE6A.description:
People are required to pay
taxes on most types of
income, including wages,
salaries, commissions, tips,
earnings on investments, and
self-employment income.

08501C8E6BC04FC0A7E5E08D3935B0E8.description:
Investigate Social Security benefits for people of different
income levels at their full retirement age.

288719F44D6545E984D4B0D7F3280CB3.description:
Given information on a worker’s income and today’s
Social Security tax rates, calculate what the worker and
the worker’s employer will pay in Social Security taxes.

D8FE16202A4A426D97FDA0F2576E858C.description:
Research the Social Security tax rate for someone who
is self-employed vs. someone who is working for an
employer.

97FE53FEE7024A8A9C9B5CCCD4FDCDC9.description:
Identify the different groups of people who qualify for
Social Security benefits.

54ED9C9C1E1E4BBF91E89C2AB98A04BC.description:
Social Security is a federal
government program that
taxes workers and employers
to provide retirement,
disability, and survivor
income benefits for workers
or their dependents.

2C9D6F90EAD140ACBE2FD1DD5CB09FF3.description: Explain how taxes impact take-home pay.

0AFC1C602766457BB65B594CF1A8D5D3.description: Identify common types of payroll deductions.

8F868FE8CAAB43EA9E22ECCC30F58045.description: Differentiate between gross and net income.

DC8D8AD6644842E29CE6E2B60CC27431.description:
Net income (take-home pay)
is the amount left from wages
and salaries after taxes and
payroll deductions.

7CBF82B86F53470A8D41C5F47CABA667.description:
Explain why families/caregivers might choose to help pay
for education and training of younger family members.

24E33326230047F1AD31436470286E65.description:
Compare the costs of post-secondary education with the
potential increase in income for a career of choice.

3D3464825E4F47A582C638CDD3AF0C19.description:
Describe the opportunity costs of attending a training
course on babysitting, lifeguarding, or first aid.

C2F3E787EFDE4BADBACDB6EBDC6F955E.description:
Education, training, and
development of job skills
have opportunity costs in
the form of time, effort, and
money.

0C024CE894B7411B9748EBE804851D29.description:
Gather data on the average wage or salary for different
jobs and explain how they differ by the level of education,
job skill, or years of experience.

BDCF6637108B43948AFE42046C8D46FA.description:
Discuss how specific skills training can improve a young
person’s human capital, productivity, and income-earning
potential.

6925E53B882D446DBD994A55B435930B.description:
Explain why adults with a college education may earn
more than adults with no education beyond high school.

61AD024A0BAF403E973573407D02040C.description:
Investigate training opportunities that can increase a
person’s ability to obtain higher paid employment during
high school.

C6AD2D7F9A4D44A89EAD559A68A002BA.description:
Getting more education,
training, and experience can
increase a person’s human
capital, productivity, and
income-earning potential.

999B500888734DC58D735D20E2DFE9DD.description:
Assess personal skills and interests and match them to
various career options.

97C00ACF08004456936A03E3AD8A79CA.description:
Conduct research on a specific career field. Describe the
education, job, or career decisions individuals in this field
might make over their lifetime and explain how this could
affect their income potential and opportunities

E428C299F61C4510B118B76F39655669.description:
Compare the education and training requirements,
income potential, and primary duties of at least two jobs
available to high school students.

2868D2DDB3A845D8A102D7506B269517.description:
People make many decisions
over a lifetime about their
education, jobs, and careers
that affect their incomes and
opportunities.

BD5DC58EFFED481A8E30C96867DF979E.description:
Interview a person who is in a career of interest and
create a timeline that shows the progression of their
education, training, and job experiences.

8089788D449A43DCAEEAA486377135D2.description:
Compare the education and training requirements for at
least two careers.

83C3FE76A77F4A60B2681AA779AB06AC.description:
Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of working in
the same occupation or profession for many years.

805926F7AA644C91BEE1D65DC689BB4F.description:
Careers are based on
working at jobs in the same
occupation or profession for
many years. Careers vary in
their education and training
requirements.
